author: Jashayla Pettigrew
title: Low-income Clark County residents identify food assistance as their top area of need
text:
KOIN Low-income Clark County residents identify food assistance as their top area of need Jashayla Pettigrew Fri, December 20, 2024 at 12:48 AM UTC 2 min read
PORTLAND, Ore. ( KOIN ) ‚Äî Low-income Clark County residents have ranked food assistance as their top area of need.
The county‚Äôs Community Services department uncovered the results of its Community Needs Assessment ‚Äî which was conducted in 2023 from Feb. 2 to April 14 ‚Äî earlier this week. Officials received nearly 900 responses from households that identify as having low income.
PacifiCorp‚Äôs rate increase reduced to 8.5% in 2025 by Oregon Public Utility Commission
Advertisement Advertisement Advertisement The survey asked residents to rank their overall needs, based on a list of options including mental health support, child care and LGBTQ+ services. According to the results, 87% of participants ranked food assistance as their top priority.
Dental services ranked in second place with 81%, while housing assistance ranked at No. 3 with 80%. Asset building and utility assistance rounded out the top five of overall needs.
After conducting the survey, Clark County hosted community forms to learn more about the results. The report shows a majority of forum attendees were not surprised by low-income households‚Äô top priorities, but some were shocked that dental services placed so highly ‚Äî while others suggested childcare, culturally-informed services and language should have ranked higher.
Oregon doctor urges vaccinations as flu cases nearly double statewide
Advertisement Advertisement Advertisement Officials noted that some responses were more common for participants within a particular demographic.
For example, respondents over 55 years old were less likely to prioritize their needs in any area other than senior services. Data also show that domestic violence services were most likely to be prioritized by those with the lowest levels of education, Medicare and Medicaid recipients and participants who identified as non-white or Hispanic or Latino.
The Community Services department last surveyed low-income residents from Nov. 1, 2019 through Jan. 31, 2020. Then, housing assistance, food assistance and asset building were ranked as the top needs for low-income households.
Oregon Attorney General-elect Rayfield creates federal oversight cabinet
Advertisement Advertisement Advertisement More in U.S. Wisconsin school shooter was in contact with a California man accused of planning separate attack, report says CNN Passengers panic as American Airlines flight ‚Äòfloods‚Äô in midair: ‚ÄòNew fear unlocked‚Äô NY Post Ex-Minnesota Vikings star Adrian Peterson facing warrants for arrest in Texas USA TODAY Sports Highest-earning NYPD cop with OT-fueled $400,000 salary retires following Daily News expos√© NY Daily News The latest assessment ‚Äúplaces a heightened focus on emerging needs and challenges‚Äù since the COVID-19 pandemic and its repercussions, Clark County representatives wrote in the report.
‚ÄúIt seeks to understand the interplay between various factors affecting low-income communities, including employment barriers, educational access, housing affordability, healthcare accessibility, and the overall social support system,‚Äù officials added. ‚ÄúThis perspective aims to inform the development of targeted, effective policies and programs that address the root causes of poverty and economic disenfranchisement in Clark County.‚Äù
Copyright 2024 Nexstar Media, Inc. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten, or redistributed.
For the latest news, weather, sports, and streaming video, head to KOIN.com.

author: Nicol√°s Schiller Solti
title: Jorge Campos juega al p√°del con Gianluigi Buffon y Andrea Pirlo previo al Juego de Leyendas en Monterrey | El Universal
text:
Este fin de semana la ciudad de Monterrey recibir√° a figuras hist√≥ricas del futbol para albergar el partido de leyendas en el estadio BBVA, como parte de las actividades de la sede previo a l Mundial 2026 . Entre ellas destacan Jorge Campos y Gianluigi Buffon , dos referentes de la porter√≠a, uno con M√©xico y otro con Italia.
Lee tambi√©n VIDEO: Juli√°n Qui√±ones es expulsado por brutal entrada en Arabia Saudita
En la previa del partido que se llevar√° a cabo este viernes en el Gigante de Acero, algunos jugadores se tomaron el tiempo de conocer la ciudad y practicar otros deportes como el p√°del.
En redes sociales, la p√°gina oficial de Monterrey como sede del Mundial 2026 comparti√≥ fotos de Andrea Pirlo , leyenda de equipos como el Inter, Milan, Juventus, acompa√±ado por Guillermo Franco , ex seleccionado mexicano y Maximiliano Rodr√≠guez , mediocampista argentino autor del m√≠tico gol contra el Tri en Alemania 2006.
Lee tambi√©n VIDEO: Chicharito Hern√°ndez y su gran gesto con la 'Hormiga' Gonz√°lez
En una de esas fotos, se observa a Campos y Buffon compartiendo un c√°lido abrazo con una sonrisa en ambos rostros.

author: Human content; AI powered search
title: Paris Hilton Sparks Controvery Over Son Not Wearing Life Jacket: VIDEO - Comic Sands
text: [Paris Hilton](https://www.buzzfeed.com/natashajokic1/paris-hilton-life-jacket-tiktok) responded to criticism after her [TikTok](https://www.comicsands.com/tag/tiktok) video of her baby boy Phoenix stumbling about onboard a moving catamaran without a life jacket sparked controversy. The 43-year-old socialite and Hilton Hotels heiress posted the clip on Tuesday with the caption: "Watching Phoenix explore the world has been so special to me! ‚ú® I am so grateful to be a [#SlivingMom]üíñ‚ú®." The video followed the one-year-old crawling and padding around the deck of the catamaran and jumping onto the netted areas above water between hulls as the watercraft was cruising at a moderate speed. You can watch the video here. [@parishilton] Watching Phoenix explore the world has been so special to me! ‚ú® I am so grateful to be a #SlivingMom üíñ‚ú® Social media users immediately shared concerns. @parishilton/TikTok @parishilton/TikTok @parishilton/TikTok @parishilton/TikTok @parishilton/TikTok @parishilton/TikTok Hilton expressed appreciation for the concern for her baby boy's safety. But instead of acknowledging the potential risk of navigating unpredictable waters with children, Hilton assured commenters that Phoenix was safe since she and her husband Carter Reum were always standing by. "Hey Mamma‚Äôs, thank you for the advice & always caring about my #CutesieCrew ü•∫ It‚Äôs a big boat & my husband and I are following him around everywhere & watching like hawks," she wrote in the comments, adding: "My babies are my world!ü•∞üíó" @ParisHilston/TikTok Although children's life jacket [requirements](https://www.boaterexam.com/boating-resources/children-personal-flotation-device/) vary from state to state, all children under the age of 13 are required to wear personal flotation devices (PFDs) while on a moving boat, according to U.S. federal law. The only exceptions are if the child is below deck, in an enclosed cabin, or if the boat is not underway. Buzzfeed noted that " [depending](https://www.uscgboating.org/regulations/state-boating-laws-details.php?id=25&title=%5B4.9%5DLife+Jackets) on the state, the size of Paris's boat may have exceeded local requirements for life jackets." Hilton's catamaran appeared to be a [Sunreef 80 Echo](https://sunreef-yachts.com/en/launched/sunreef-80-eco-141/), which is roughly 80 feet in length. Users weighed in on her clapback. @parishilton/TikTok @parishilton/TikTok @parishilton/TikTok This was not the first time Phoenix was spotted near water without a life jacket. Earlier this month, Hilton posted a summer vacation compilation [TikTok](https://www.tiktok.com/@parishilton/video/7398709284739042591) showing Phoenix sitting on the edge of a deck above water. In December 2019, Hilton began dating Reum, a longtime friend of the Hilton family who is an author, entrepreneur, and venture capitalist who founded the angel investment firm M13. The couple tied the knot in Los Angeles on November 11, 2021. In addition to having Phoenix Barron Hilton Reum, the couple also have a daughter, London Marilyn Hilton Reum. Both children were born via surrogacy in January 2023 and November 2023, respectively. Last October, Hilton defended Phoenix against internet trolls who [mocked](https://www.comicsands.com/paris-hilton-sons-head-trolls-2666053718.html) the child with mean comments about the shape and size of his head after she posted a photo of her holding the then eight-month-old during a trip to New York City. Some people wondered if the child was suffering from a medical abnormality such as encephalitis, a condition involving inflammation of the brain and spinal cord. Another urged Hilton to have her infant son "evaluated by a pediatric surgeon" and get an MRI "to rule out a blockage of spinal fluid in his brain just to be on the safe side." One commented, "Something's not right" while another drew a comparison with "Stewie," the Family Guy cartoon toddler with a disproportionately large cranium that resembled a [football](https://www.comicsands.com/tag/football). In response to the unsolicited concerns and suggestions, she wrote: "ü•∫üò¢There are some sick people in this world.‚òπÔ∏èMy angel is perfectly healthy." "And yes, of course he has been to a doctor, he just has a large brain."

author: GoldSeek Headlines
title: GoldSeek Radio Nugget - Bob Hoye: Gold‚Äôs Real Price Is Relative to Mining Costs | GoldSeek
text: Bob Hoye, market historian and author from [Charts & Markets.com](https://chartsandmarkets.com/), thinks the holiday cheer is over and the "everything bubble" may burst! - As the cost of mining bullion declines, gold miners are becoming more profitable: Hoye elaborates: "I don't put too much effort into the gold price in dollar terms. As I mentioned, that's the old mantra 'Dollar down gold, up, gold stocks up' and that speculation in foreign exchange markets...and I've gone to the real price and taken gold and divided it by the CRB [Commodity Research Bureau Index]. With the suggestion that CRB is a proxy for mining costs, and then when you divide by crude oil, and you consider that about 60%. Actually, operating a mine is energy-related, you know, you've got those big diesel trucks and blasting agents and all that sort of stuff. So this is where gold price relative to costs is going up. Now I saw a more famous name the other day, saying that gold was going to go to $15,000. What happens if crude oil goes to 40,000 and they don't make any money? So that's the old dollar down, gold up, gold stocks up story. And I've seen this guy usually come up with a $10,000 target when you get a rally. And this time, as the first I've seen $15,000, which is bizarre. So the main thing is that the cost, bullion price is rising relative to the costs of mining ‚Äì and this is why in previous post-bubble depressions, the mining sector has become the big game in town and you have miners making money ‚Äì and because the pricing pressures are so severe in the post-bubble contraction, most industries in commerce are really not making any money...but because the costs for mining gold are going down, 'Hey, the gold miners make money!' and it's been doing it for a long time." - Bob outlines his unique analysis of the deflated price of gold over hundreds of years. - The small cap mining stocks are oversold and showing excellent signs of life. - A review of the price of gold relative to the commodities index, i.e., inflation adjusted gold - notice that when the blue line - 50 week moving average is up, the gold price tends to advance: Pls. add our show Q&A text number (24/7) to your friends list: 8285541203 YEAR for gold and silver join our Substack: You can support the show by subscribing to [our Substack](https://goldseekradio.substack.com/) with Gold Juniors and Bitcoin Investments.

author: Lynda V. Mapes, The Seattle Times The Tribune Content Agency
title: Climate, energy upheavals roil Northwest power market
text:
Seattle
Climate, energy upheavals roil Northwest power market
Heat domes. Cold snaps. Winter storms - even as far away as Texas. Extreme weather events are roiling power markets and spiking power prices for energy providers and their customers.
This increasing volatility - and mandates to decarbonize energy supplies, introducing more variable energy sources, such as wind and solar power - is driving big changes for regional utilities, including how they buy and sell power.
In play right now is a realignment of Northwest utilities into new energy markets. Power managers here hope these broader markets will give them reliable access to electricity and at lower rates when they don't produce enough on their own, which can happen in drier years or during extreme weather events.
Power managers hope a refreshed market landscape will increase the reliability of energy and keep costs lower for consumers.
Two power market operators are contending for Northwest utilities' business: the Southwest Power Pool's Markets+, based in Arkansas, and the California Independent System Operator.
This is a complex topic, so let's step back to see what's new.
Around the region, utilities buy and sell energy to meet customers' needs, moving power around a connected power grid. That is not new.
What is changing is the creation of these larger pools of utilities over a bigger geographic footprint, with an operator that optimizes trades not just minute to minute but for a whole day. That is intended to help utilities smooth challenges of variability in both weather and energy sources.
As these new market pools shape up, all eyes are on the Bonneville Power Administration.
A nonprofit federal administration, the BPA is self-funded by revenues from selling power and transmission services across 15,000 miles of high-voltage power lines. The juice comes from 31 federal dams and one nuclear plant, which produce about 32% of the power generated in the Northwest, sold wholesale to 142 retail customers - utilities large and small across 300,000 square miles in eight states.
Some get all their energy from BPA. Others, such as Seattle City Light, supplement their own generation with purchases from BPA. Typically, Seattle City Light gets 40% of its customers' power from BPA - even more in low-water years, such as last year.
BPA has held multiple briefings and workshops to help lead the process as the region remakes its energy market. BPA staff in a white paper last year recommended BPA jump in the pool operated by Markets+.
But with the players in the two power pools still shaping up, some powerful policymakers are urging BPA to pump the brakes.
Aligning with energy partners in the Southwest Power Pool's Markets+ initiative is projected to be, under some scenarios, $79 to $129 million more costly in 2026 for Bonneville - and its ratepayers - compared to business as usual, according to a study commissioned by BPA. U.S. senators for the Northwest wrote in a letter to BPA on Dec. 13 that there is no scenario evaluated in the study that demonstrated financial benefits in choosing the Markets+ alternative.
BPA counters that while initial costs in the first few years of Markets+ participation are more costly, those costs level out and BPA contends the long-term picture eventually is financially beneficial for customers.
But why eat the extra cost? And why the hurry? The senators asked and urged BPA to do nothing for now and wait out changes expected in California law this session that could put to rest concerns about the governance of that market pool.
PacifiCorp, PGE, Seattle City Light and three major electrical worker unions in Portland, Tacoma and Seattle also urged BPA to change nothing for now in a letter sent to BPA this week, urging BPA to avoid additional costs for customers already facing rate increases.
Heavy hitter customers that guzzle power, including Amazon, Google, Microsoft and Rivian, also in a public comment sent to BPA's administrator stated Bonneville has not sufficiently considered the impact to ratepayers and any decision now is premature. A host of environmental groups and green energy advocates have also urged BPA to give this decision more time to more fully consider both economic and environmental impacts before making its move.
But with some area utilities already declaring their market preferences, BPA must make a decision, or will find itself isolated, with limited options, said Rachel Dibble, vice president for bulk power marketing at BPA. "We have to make a choice," Dibble said. "Or everything will change around us and our options will be limited. Not to make a choice is a choice."
Chelan, Grant and Snohomish counties' PUDs and Tacoma Power have each indicated a preference for Markets+. For Tacoma Power, the decision came down to reliability and independent governance, said Chris Robinson, general manager and chief operating officer for the utility.
Being hosted by a market run by a California entity didn't seem like a good deal, Robinson said, and he didn't want to wait on legislation in California to sort that out, either. "We have this opportunity right in front of us; we think it is important to move forward," Robinson said.
But Dawn Lindell, general manager for Seattle City Light, isn't feeling the Markets+ love. She said she is concerned about reliability and affordability for the utility's customers.
"I want to know, do I have paths by which I can get the energy and send the energy, and is it what makes economic sense?" said Lindell. "We have 113,000 customers at or below 60% of average income, it matters a lot what we charge. ... I am looking for the least cost, most effective option."
Climate change is roiling power markets
Extreme weather events are upending reliability and price for the region's hydropower. The graph below reveals daily high prices in the Pacific Northwest mid-Columbia power market from 2001 to 2024. Peaks coincide with major storms, heat waves and other disruptions.
U.S. Energy Information Administration (Fiona Martin / The Seattle Times)
Weather events of the last four years compared with the previous 20 have gotten the utility's attention, Lindell said, offering a graph that shows spikes in power prices on the market as jagged as the extreme temperatures that necessitated the power purchases.
"You can see climate change in the graph, it is very impactful over the last four years and every time we have a high (temperature) day or a low day, we have to go on the market and it is very expensive," Lindell said.
"These weather events are driving the need for a very good and cost-effective way of buying and selling energy."
The larger storms wrought by climate change also make the creation of a larger market into which to sell and from which to buy sensible - to escape weather patterns that spike prices. "Storms are stronger, last longer and affect a much bigger land mass," Lindell added.
"We need trading markets where the weather is different. ... I would love a ginormous footprint that covers a lot of ground, north and south, and we want as noncarbon emitting sources as we can find."
BPA has announced it will make a preliminary decision on market choice March 6 and a final decision in May.
Copyright (C) 2025, Tribune Content Agency, LLC. Portions copyrighted by the respective providers.

author: Abb√© Alain Ren√© Arbez
title: L'Eglise catholique est-elle la Babylone corrompue, la grande prostitu√©e de l'apocalypse ?
text:
C‚Äôest ce que pr√©tendent constamment certains courants √©vang√©liques litt√©ralistes, qui sans m√™me s‚Äôen rendre compte, interpr√®tent des passages du Nouveau testament √† partir de leur a-priori id√©ologique. Il convient donc d‚Äôexaminer les textes de r√©f√©rence pour v√©rifier comment s‚Äôarticule cette accusation fr√©quente du catho-bashing habituel. L‚Äôid√©e d‚Äôassimiler l‚ÄôEglise catholique √† Babylone s‚Äôappuie sur le chapitre 17 de l‚ÄôApocalypse, o√π l‚Äôon voit la femme assise sur 7 collines, et o√π les 7 t√™tes sont 7 collines sur lesquelles la femme est install√©e. Certes, on est habitu√© √† parler de Rome comme de ¬´ la ville aux 7 collines ¬ª. Mais l‚Äôargument est un peu court. S‚Äôagit-il ici de Rome, la ville pa√Øenne, ou de l‚ÄôEglise catholique elle-m√™me ?
N‚Äôallons pas trop vite en besogne, car le mot grec utilis√© dans le nouveau testament pour dire ¬´ colline ¬ª est ¬´ horos ¬ª, qu‚Äôon retrouve 65 fois dans l‚Äôensemble des textes n√©o-testamentaires. Or dans la version King James de la Bible c‚Äôest seulement 3 occurrences qui sont rendues par ¬´ colline ¬ª. Les 62 autres sont traduites par ¬´ montagne ¬ª.
Si la ¬´ prostitu√©e ¬ª de l‚Äôapocalypse se tient sur 7 montagnes, rappelons-nous que le terme montagne est un symbole biblique connu qui d√©signe les royaumes (ps 68, Dan 2.35, Amos 4,1, etc). Ainsi, les montagnes de la prostitu√©e sont en fait les royaumes o√π elle r√®gne, on sait aussi que le chiffre 7 exprime la pl√©nitude. Ce qui sugg√®rerait que la prostitu√©e r√®gne sur tous les royaumes de la terre. C‚Äôest donc clairement une critique spirituelle des pouvoirs temporels souvent inhumains et cruels.
Et m√™me si l‚Äôon gardait le mot ¬´ colline ¬ª, rien ne prouve qu‚Äôil s‚Äôagisse sp√©cialement de Rome, bien qu‚Äôil soit √©vident que la Rome pa√Øenne correspondait √† l‚Äôoppression, aux injustices et √† la d√©bauche ici d√©nonc√©es. C‚Äô√©tait effectivement l‚Äôambiance dominante, √† l‚Äô√©poque des pers√©cutions, quand Pierre et Paul √©vang√©lisent et se trouvent √† Rome.
Lorsque c‚Äôest le Vatican qui est cibl√©, il est utile de rappeler que celui-ci a √©t√© construit sur une seule colline et pas sur 7‚Ä¶Les 7 collines sur lesquelles Rome est construite se situent √† l‚Äôest du Tibre, tandis que le Vatican est construit √† l‚Äôouest. Pas de correspondance, par cons√©quent.
Dans Apoc. 17,10, il est √©crit que les 7 t√™tes correspondent √† 7 rois. On ne peut y voir le Vatican qui n‚Äôexiste pas encore √† l‚Äô√©poque. Par ailleurs, il y a beaucoup de villes dans le monde qui sont situ√©es sur 7 collines : Paris, N√Æmes, Besan√ßon, St Etienne, Washington, New York, Cincinatti, Lynchburg, Lisbonne, Bamberg, Bath, Yaound√©, Antananarivo, Pretoria, Alger, Istambul, et beaucoup d‚Äôautres !
On peut aussi penser que l‚Äôallusion aux 7 collines ou montagnes √©voque J√©rusalem. Le th√©ologien protestant Martin note que dans le Pirke du rabbi Eliezer (8 √®me s.) il est pr√©cis√© : ¬´ J√©rusalem b√¢tie sur 7 montagnes ¬ª . Un mont correspond √† la r√©alit√© d√©nonc√©e : une de ces montagnes est en effet d√©nomm√© ¬´ le mont de la corruption ¬ª ou ¬´ de la perdition ¬ª.
Il est √©galement utile de v√©rifier si la prostitu√©e de l‚Äôapocalypse d√©signe vraiment Babylone, mentionn√©e 5 fois dans le livre visionnaire. Depuis le temps de l‚Äôexil, n‚Äôoublions pas que Babylone symbolise l‚Äôidol√¢trie, la tyrannie et la luxure. La tradition h√©bra√Øque donne souvent des noms symboliques pour d√©signer les d√©voiements de certaines villes. Ainsi, Sodome pour stigmatiser la d√©bauche, Egypte pour caract√©riser un pays idol√¢tre, et Canaan pour avertir une population frapp√©e de mal√©diction.
Ce qui fait que Babylone peut d√©signer Rome, c‚Äôest ce que l‚Äôon peut lire dans la premi√®re lettre de Pierre. Babylone, Rome la grande cit√© ‚Ä¶Mais ces termes accusateurs se retrouvent aussi pour √©voquer J√©rusalem ! ¬´ La grande cit√© appel√©e Sodome et Egypte, l√† m√™me o√π leur Seigneur a √©t√© crucifi√©‚Ä¶ ¬ª (Apoc 11,7)
Devenez ¬´ lecteur premium ¬ª, pour avoir acc√®s √† une navigation sans publicit√©, et nous soutenir financi√®rement pour continuer de d√©fendre vos id√©es !
En tant que lecteur premium, vous pouvez √©galement participer √† la discussion et publier des commentaires.
Montant libre
Don ponctuel
1‚Ç¨ (Acc√®s 1 jour) 5‚Ç¨ (Acc√®s 1 mois) 10‚Ç¨ (Acc√®s 2 mois) 20‚Ç¨ (Acc√®s 4 mois) 50‚Ç¨ (Acc√®s 1 an) 100‚Ç¨ (Acc√®s 2 ans) 260‚Ç¨ (Donateur Prestige illimit√©) 500‚Ç¨ (Donateur Prestige illimit√©) 1000‚Ç¨ (Donateur Ambassadeur illimit√©) 7500‚Ç¨ (Donateur Ambassadeur illimit√©)
Don Mensuel
5‚Ç¨/mois 10‚Ç¨/mois 20‚Ç¨/mois 50‚Ç¨/mois
Dans Isa√Øe 1,10 et Ezekiel 16,1, comment sont caract√©ris√©s les ennemis de l‚Äôalliance ? ¬´ Sodome, Egypte et Babylone ¬ª. Les p√®res de l‚ÄôEglise se sont souvent r√©f√©r√©s √† cette symbolique pour la mise en cause de J√©rusalem infid√®le √† Dieu, mais ils ont aussi vis√© la Rome pa√Øenne qui pers√©cute f√©rocement les chr√©tiens.
Dans Apocalypse 17,1, il est question du ¬´ jugement de la grande prostitu√©e avec laquelle les rois de la terre se sont souill√©s ¬ª alors que les ¬´ habitants de la terre se sont enivr√©s du vin de son impudicit√© ¬ª‚Ä¶ Dans la bible, la prostitution d√©signe l‚Äôinfid√©lit√© envers Dieu. C‚Äôest le sens d‚Äôune rupture d‚Äôalliance que l‚Äôon retrouve majoritairement. Dans Isa√Øe 1,21, les deux royaumes d‚ÄôIsra√´l et de Juda sont mis en cause : ¬´ Comment est-elle devenue une prostitu√©e la cit√© fid√®le, pleine d‚Äô√©quit√©, o√π habitent maintenant des meurtriers‚Ä¶ ¬ª ¬´ qu‚Äôa fait J√©rusalem l‚Äôinfid√®le, elle est all√©e sur toute montagne et s‚Äôy est prostitu√©e‚Ä¶et Juda la perfide, est all√©e se prostituer aussi, elle a commis l‚Äôadult√®re avec le bois et la pierre‚Ä¶ ¬ª
Il s‚Äôagit ici clairement des d√©voiements idol√¢triques qui ont perverti la vie des croyants et les ont d√©tourn√©s du Dieu vivant. L‚Äôadult√®re est souvent la mani√®re de dire que le peuple a tromp√© Dieu en transgressant le lien d‚Äôamour qui le reliait √† lui.
Il ressort de ces passages bibliques que l‚Äôapostasie est vigoureusement d√©nonc√©e, et que c‚Äôest essentiellement J√©rusalem qui est cibl√©e.
En conclusion, ce parcours d‚Äôanalyse des termes bibliques r√©v√®le que l‚Äôaccusation de l‚ÄôEglise catholique en tant que ¬´ prostitu√©e ¬ª ou ¬´ Babylone ¬ª ne correspond en rien √† la contextualisation loyale des passages cit√©s en r√©f√©rence. Il s‚Äôagit en r√©alit√© d‚Äôun transfert fantasmatique inappropri√©.
Toute communaut√© chr√©tienne, quelle qu‚Äôelle soit, peut sous tel ou tel aspect se trouver cibl√©e par la critique de trahison de l‚Äôalliance famili√®re aux √©crits proph√©tiques et au style du livre de l‚ÄôApocalypse. L‚ÄôEglise est sainte, mais ses membres sont p√©cheurs.
Reproduction autoris√©e avec la mention suivante : ¬© Abb√© Alain Ren√© Arbez, pr√™tre catholique, commission jud√©o-catholique de la conf√©rence des √©v√™ques suisses et de la f√©d√©ration suisse des communaut√©s isra√©lites, pour Dreuz.info .
Abonnez-vous sans tarder √† notre cha√Æne Telegram, pour le cas o√π Dreuz soit censur√©, ou son acc√®s coup√©. Cliquez ici : Dreuz.Info.Telegram .

author: @wsaw
title: Pro-life protestors rally as abortion services resume in Sheboygan
text: Pro-life protestors rally as abortion services resume in Sheboygan SHEBOYGAN, Wis. (WBAY) - Pro-life advocates held a prayer rally outside of the Planned Parenthood clinic in Sheboygan after the facility resumed abortion health care services Thursday. PPWI says Dane County Circuit Court Judge Diane Schlipper [made a ruling](https://www.wbay.com/2023/12/06/planned-parenthood-wisconsin-plans-resume-abortion-services-sheboygan-after-court-ruling/) earlier this month that reaffirmed a previous decision which said statute 940.04 (Wisconsin‚Äôs 1849 law on abortion) does not apply to consensual abortion care. Pro-life groups objected to the ruling. Those taking part in the prayer rally believe abortion services claim innocent lives. ‚ÄúThey will never have a voice, so we must be the voice for them,‚Äù said Dan Miller, the State Director of Pro-Life Wisconsin. Miller said he is hopeful about an appeal of the judge‚Äôs ruling, made by Sheboygan County District Attorney Joel Urmanski. Meanwhile, Dr. Kristin Lyerly, an OB-GYN, who previously independently contracted at the Sheboygan clinic, says she doesn‚Äôt believe the ruling will be overturned. ‚ÄúPeople need health care,‚Äù said Dr. Lyerly. ‚ÄúPeople have the same kinds of needs they deserve access, they deserve support, they deserve resources, and that‚Äôs not what politicians in Wisconsin are giving them right now.‚Äù Representatives from Planned Parenthood say patients can now make appointments at the Sheboygan location. PREVIOUS REPORT: Abortion health care services resume at Planned Parenthood‚Äôs Sheboygan Health Center Thursday. Now, the location joins two others already offering abortions again in Milwaukee and Madison. PPWI says Dane County Circuit Court Judge Diane Schlipper [made a ruling](https://www.wbay.com/2023/12/06/planned-parenthood-wisconsin-plans-resume-abortion-services-sheboygan-after-court-ruling/) earlier this month that reaffirmed a previous decision which said statute 940.04 (Wisconsin‚Äôs 1849 law on abortion) does not apply to consensual abortion care. Pro-life groups objected to the ruling. Both sides are responding to medication abortions restarting. Planned Parenthood of Wisconsin‚Äôs President and CEO Tanya Atkinson said, ‚ÄúBeing able to provide this essential care at another health center is important to the health and well-being of Wisconsin women and people across the gender spectrum who need care.‚Äù Non-profit Pro-Life Wisconsin is holding an anti-abortion rally outside Planned Parenthood in Sheboygan in response. The group‚Äôs social media post announcing the rally and prayer gathering says, ‚ÄúOur hope is to attempt to open the hearts and minds of both abortion workers and pregnant mothers. Help us to keep the unborn alive and unharmed.‚Äù Planned Parenthood representatives say schedules are open for patients to book appointments at the Sheboygan location right now. The rally is set to begin at 10:30 a.m. Copyright 2023 WBAY. All rights reserved.
